descriptionProfile: Creating visual case studies on masculinity, conflict and social order. Nat Geo, Wash Post, TIME & more. Nairobi, Kenya.
Creating visual case studies on masculinity, conflict and social order. Nat Geo, Wash Post, TIME & more. Nairobi, Kenya.

posts.description: DC friends! This coming Tuesday, April 25, I'll join fellow photographer @stephsinclairpix and @natgeo Editor-In-Chief Susan Goldberg for a conversation on #gender at the National Geographic Museum in Washington, DC. Stephanie and I will each present elements of our respective bodies of work before discussing them with Susan and the audience. It'll be an interesting evening for sure. Link to full details and tickets in bio. Hope to see some of you there! #DC #gender #boyhood #masculinity #genderrevolution #events

This evening I'll be in conversation about my work with Jon Western, Dean of Faculty of Mount Holyoke College, at the Mount Holyoke College Art Museum. We'll talk chat about armed conflict, masculinity, art and visual journalism. The event is free and open to the public. Drop by if you're in the area. #MHC #museum #art #mountholyokecollege #photography #photographer

A wonderful afternoon at the @clarkart Institute in Williamstown, Massachusetts. This is one of the finest and most unassuming presentations of art that I've ever seen. To reach the Institute, one drives through the scenic and rural hills of the #berkshires where one might not expect to discover this world class collection. A beautiful research center and library to boot! Here, an extraordinary picture by Sir Lawrence Alma-Tadema entitled The Women of Amphissa. A must see if you find yourself in this part of the world. #massachusetts #art #museum #berkshires
The @abbrewery in Easthampton, MA, feels like you're drinking craft beers in your living room--if you had a really cool living room. Amazing. #newengland #MA #westernmass #brewery

The large boulders behind my friend, Joe, make up what's known as King Phillips Cave in the town of Norton, #Massachusetts. King Phillip's War was a campaign of fierce, cyclical violence that occurred between 1675 and 1676 between English settlers and the Wampanoag, Nipmuck and Narragansett Indians. It is widely regarded as the largest loss of life (per capita) in the history of the United States and a key event in the formation of colonial identity in the territories. I grew up in Massachusetts and learned virtually nothing about it in our public schools. It felt deeply disconcerting to cross the street from Joe's house, past a string of newly-constructed million-dollar homes, to this small protected site. As we explored the rock formations and thought about what they signified, a man ran a snow blower on the driveway of his palatial home. During my visiting professorship at Mount Holyoke College, I've been reading an incredible book about King Phillip's War by historian Jill Lepore. An important book for all. #MA #nativeamerican #wanpanoag #kingphilipswar #winter #newengland

My father, Norman, sits at the head of the table during his retirement party. He's characteristically more interested in his soup than in conversation ðŸ˜‰. He's retiring after a 35-year stint as the art conservator at the @princeton_university Art Museum. Beyond the Princeton museum, he has more than 50 years of experience in the field of art conservation. It's remarkable to consider. I drove from Massachusetts to New Jersey for the night to attend the celebration of his contribution. Time marches on. What a bitter sweet affair. #dad #retirement

For the first time in many years, my mother and I celebrated our birthdays together. They fall a week apart in the depths of winter and are therefore often quiet affairs. This year, we enjoyed a lovely dinner prepared by my sister, Irene, exchanged a few, small gifts and took advantage of the opportunity to be together. One of the most wonderful things about teaching at Mount Holyoke College this semester is its proximity to my family in eastern Massachusetts. Coming home so often makes me painfully aware of how much I miss when I'm so far away. I'm very grateful to have this time together. #family #USA #birthdays #winter

The winters in Massachusetts are as tough as I remember--but sledding helps a little. We've had two significant snow storms over the last week and they've left me thinking. I'm immersed in literature about the human propensity to band together in order to confront challenges. Many scholars argue that modern humans have been naturally selected for our ability to cooperate in the face of threats; that those who failed to participate died and therefore left fewer descendants. While a snowstorm in the modern era poses nominal risk, I can't help but feel that it ignites something primordial within us. In particular, I think it does something to men, who suddenly feel needed. A snowstorm creates a small window in which male physical strength becomes an valuable commodity. They can more easily shovel wet heavy snow, push out vehicles and execute other tasks in which strength is an asset. As much as we claim to hate these storms, I think they evoke something important and meaningful within us. #massachusetts #USA #snow #winteriscoming #winter #ipswich

After a couple of crazy and rather distressing days, I retreated to the ocean front in Lynn, Massachusetts, near where I grew up. No phone. No distractions. Just waves crashing against the sea wall and brisk winter air. "Go placidly amid the noise and the haste, and remember what peace there may be in silence." Time to focus on actual, constructive contributions. #Lynn #Massachusetts #dailylife #ocean #water
Tens of thousands on Boston Common in support of women's rights. A lively, affirming and inclusive crowd. #womensmarch #boston #trump #equality
